case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Co., Ltd. v. Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta

facts.text: Tata Iron and Steel Co., Ltd. filed Petition No. 199 of 1959 under Article 32 challenging tax demand.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 199 of 1959. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. V. Viswanatha Sastri, N. A. Palkhivala S. N. Andley, J. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Company challenges authority of Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta, to demand Rs. 41,14,718.12 nP. as tax under Central Sales Tax Act 1956 on sales of steel goods.

anchor.surface_text: By this petition for writs of certiorari and mandamus, the Tata Iron and Steel Co., Ltd., hereinafter referred to as the-company, challenges the authority of the Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta, to demand payment of Rs. 41,14,718.12 nP. to the West Bengal Government as tax leviable under the Central Sales Tax Act No. 74 of 1956 in respect of certain sales of steel goods.

facts.text: Company has registered office in Bombay, Head Sales office in Calcutta (West Bengal), factories in Jamshedpur (Bihar).

anchor.surface_text: The companypany has its registered office in Bombay, its Head Sales office in Calcutta in the State of West Bengal and its factories in Jamshedpur in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: Company registered as dealer under Bihar Sales Tax Act and under Central Sales Tax Act 1956 in West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany is registered as a dealer under the Bihar Sales Tax Act, and is also registered as a dealer in the State of West Bengal under the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

facts.text: For assessment period July 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958, company submitted return to CTO Calcutta disclosing gross taxable turnover Rs. 9,561-71 nP.

anchor.surface_text: For the period of assessment July 1, 1957, to March 31, 1958, the companypany submitted its return of taxable sales to the Commer- cial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta, disclosing a gross taxable turnover of Rs. 9,561-71 nP. in respect of sales liable to Central sales tax in the State of West Bengal.

facts.text: CTO memorandum dated August 12, 1959 directed company to submit statement of sales from Jamshedpur where documents transferred in West Bengal or other sales under s.3(b) CST Act.

anchor.surface_text: By his memorandum dated August 12, 1959, the Commercial Tax Officer directed the companypany to submit a statement of sales from Jamshedpur for the period under assessment, documents relating to which were transferred in West Bengal or of any other sales that may have taken place in West Bengal under s. 3 b  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 .

facts.text: Company by letter dated September 30, 1959 informed CTO that requisition without jurisdiction, all sales from Jamshedpur under s.3(a), situs Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany, by its letter dated September 30, 1959, informed the Tax Officer that the requisition for production of statement of sales made from Jamshedpur in the companyrse of inter-State trade or companymerce was without jurisdiction. The companypany companytended that all the sales from Jamshedpur were of the type mentioned in s. 3 a  of the Central Sales Tax Act and at the same time, some of them also fell within the category mentioned in s. 3 b  of the Act , that even if the sales were of the type mentioned in s. 3 b  of the Act, the appropriate State of the place where the sales take place or are effected alone had jurisdiction to assess such sales to Central sales tax , and that in respect of inter-State sales from Jamshedpur, the situs of the sale was always the State of Bihar as the goods were in Bihar either at the time of the companytract of sale or at the time of appropriation to the companytract.

facts.text: CTO order dated October 21, 1959 made best judgment assessment on gross turnover Rs. 9,00,09,561.71 nP., demanded tax Rs. 41,14,718.12 nP.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated October 21, 1959, the Commercial Tax Officer made a best judgment assessment on a gross turnover of Rs. 9,00,09,561.71 nP. of interState sales and called upon the companypany to pay Rs. 41,14,718.12 nP. as tax under the Central Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Company filed returns of inter-State sales from Jamshedpur with STO Jamshedpur on December 15, 1958 for period July 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958, total turnover exceeded Rs. 26 crores, paid Rs. 71 lakhs advance tax under CST.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany had, on December 15, 1958, filed with the Sales Tax Officer, Jamshedpur, a return of interState sales made from Jamshedpur for the period July 1, 1957, to March 31, 1958, and a return for the same period for the sales made from Dhanbad with the Sales Tax Officer, Dhanbad. In these returns, the companypany included all sales in which movement of the goods had taken place from the State of Bihar to destinations outside that State. The total turnover in respect of such inter-State sales as shown in the return exceeded Rs. 26 crores and the companypany paid as required by the Bihar Sales Tax Act Rs. 71 lakhs odd as advance tax under the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 29, 1960 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 29. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-

facts.text: Company paid tax to Bihar on turnover including sales taxed by WB CTO.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently, the companypany has paid to the Sales Tax Officer, Bihar, tax due under the Central Sales Tax Act on its turnover including sales on which the tax is sought to be levied by the Commercial Tax Officer, West Bengal.

facts.text: Court holds petition under Art 32 maintainable as threat of double tax infringes Art 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The companypany having paid the tax to the Bihar State for and on behalf of the Central Government, the threat to recover again sales tax on behalf of the Central Government in respect of the same sales, i. e., sales which are included in the assessment proceedings before the Bihar Sales Tax authorities prima facie infringes the fundamental right of the companypany to hold its property and the companypany is entitled to approach this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: CTO assessed sales under s.3(b) assuming transfer of documents in WB makes WB appropriate state.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer has observed in his order that In this case, it should be remembered that section 3 b  refers to transfer of documents and number only to transfer of documents by endorsement. Thus, even if the documents are in the name of the buyer as companysignee but these are physically transferred to the buyer in West Bengal then that sale is taxable in West Bengal.

facts.text: Court quashes assessment order dated Oct 21, 1959 as error apparent, directs reassessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the companyrect tests and has made assumptions which are number warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment.

facts.text: Sales of iron and steel controlled by Iron and Steel Control Order 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by companynsel for the State of Bihar that iron and steel are companymodities of which the storage, sale and purchase are companytrolled by the Iron and Steel  Control  Order, 1956,

facts.text: Company impugns validity of CTO order, seeks certiorari quashing it and mandamus restraining enforcement.

anchor.surface_text: By this petition the companypany impugns the validity of the order of the Commercial Tax Officer and claims a writ of certiorari quashing and setting aside the assessment order dated October 21, 1959, and a writ of mandamus directing the Commercial Tax Officer to refrain from taking steps in enforcement or implementation of the order.

facts.text: Respondents contend petition not maintainable under Art 32 as no fundamental right infringed.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondents companytends that the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is number maintainable because numberfundamental right of the companypany is infringed by the order passed by the Commercial Tax Officer and the remedy of the companypany, if it feels aggrieved by the order, is to seek relief by resorting to the machinery provided by the West Bengal Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Sarkar J. also delivers judgment setting aside assessment.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order made by the Taxing Officer of the Government of West Bengal on October 21, 1959, assessing the petitioner to a tax of Rs. 41,14,718- 12nP.

facts.text: Assessment period July 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958 covered by Act as stood prior to amendment Oct 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This case however has to be decided on the Act as it stood prior to the amendment, for the period companyered by the impugned order of assessment was from July 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958.

facts.text: Company contends all sales from Jamshedpur under s.3(a), situs Bihar per s.4(2).

anchor.surface_text: We companytend that all our sales from Jamshedpur are. of the type mentioned in Section 3 a  of the Central Sales Tax Act and at the same time some of them also fall within the category mentioned in Section 3 b  of the Act. Even if the sales are of the type mentioned in Section 3 b  of the Act, the Appropriate State of the place where the sales take place or are effected, has jurisdiction to assess such sales to Central Sales Tax.
Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. V. Viswanatha Sastri, N. A. Palkhivala S. N. Andley, J. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondents contends that the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is not maintainable because no fundamental right of the company is infringed by the order passed by the Commercial Tax Officer and the remedy of the company, if it feels aggrieved by the order, is to seek relief by resorting to the machinery provided by the West Bengal Sales Tax Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Threat of double taxation infringes Art.19(1)(g); distinguishes Ramjilal and Laxmanappa, follows Himmatlal, Bengal Immunity.

arguments.claim: All sales from Jamshedpur are under s.3(a) CST Act; even if some under s.3(b), appropriate state is where sale takes place/effected (situs Bihar per s.4(2) as goods in Bihar at contract or appropriation).

anchor.surface_text: The company, by its letter dated September 30, 1959, informed the Tax Officer that the requisition for production of statement of sales made from Jamshedpur in the course of inter-State trade or commerce was without jurisdiction. The company contended that all the sales from Jamshedpur were of the type mentioned in s. 3 a  of the Central Sales Tax Act

arguments.court_reasoning: s.3(a)/(b) mutually exclusive; for s.3(b), situs where documents transferred per s.2(a) Expl.II, not s.4(2); s.4 subject to s.3.

arguments.claim: For s.3(b) sales, appropriate state is where documents of title transferred to buyer (physically in WB, even without endorsement if consigned to self); s.4(2) inapplicable to inter-state sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer has observed in his order that In this case, it should be remembered that section 3 b  refers to transfer of documents and not only to transfer of documents by endorsement. Thus, even if the documents are in the name of the buyer as consignee but these are physically transferred to the buyer in West Bengal then that sale is taxable in West Bengal.

arguments.court_reasoning: Transfer must pass property; place of sale per s.4(2) or s.2(a); error apparent as assumptions unwarranted, no evidence of movement/doc transfer passing property.

arguments.claim: Threat of double taxation (already paid to Bihar) infringes Art.19(1)(g), making Art.32 petition maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The company having paid the tax to the Bihar State for and on behalf of the Central Government, the threat to recover again sales tax on behalf of the Central Government in respect of the same sales, i. e., sales which are included in the assessment proceedings before the Bihar Sales Tax authorities prima facie infringes the fundamental right of the company to hold its property

arguments.claim: Sections 3(a) and 3(b) are mutually exclusive to avoid double taxation; 3(a) covers movement by contract where property not passed by doc transfer; 3(b) where property passes by doc transfer during movement.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of an inter-State sale, the tax is leviable only once and that indicates that the two clauses of s. 3 are mutually exclusive. A sale taxable as falling within cl. a  of s. 3, will be excluded from the purview of cl. b  of s. 3 otherwise certain sales may, be liable to tax under both the clauses

arguments.claim: For s.3(b), appropriate state is place where sale effected i.e. where documents of title transferred (s.2(a) Expl.II); s.4(2) subject to s.3, applies to non-interstate sales only.

anchor.surface_text: appropriate State was at the material time defined by s. 2 a as follows Appropriate State means- in relation to a dealer who has one or more places of business ... Explanation- Place of business means, in the case of a sale of goods in the course of inter- State trade or commerce falling within cl. a  of s. 3, the place from which the goods have been moved ... cl. b  of s. 3, the place where the sale is effected.

arguments.claim: All sales under s.3(a) due to Iron and Steel Control Order 1956 controlling storage/sale/purchase, property passes at appropriation in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by counsel for the State of Bihar that iron and steel are commodities of which the storage, sale and purchase are controlled by the Iron and Steel  Control  Order, 1956, and all the sales which are made subject to tax under the impugned order are those covered by s. 3 a  of the Central Sales Tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: different matter. Further sub-cl.  ii  of the Explanation in s. 2 a  specifies the place of business and s. 4 2  specifies a State so the latter canno

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide without complete picture of modus operandi.

arguments.claim: CTO assessment discloses error apparent on face: failed to verify if s.3(b) (goods in movement, doc transfer passes property), situs per s.4(2) in WB; unwarranted assumptions; best judgment without evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment.

arguments.claim: s.3(b) sale effected where property passes by transfer of documents of title during movement; appropriate state where transfer occurs (s.2(a) Expl.II); s.4(2) not for inter-state sales.

anchor.surface_text: Two questions arise, namely, what is a sale under s. 3(b) and which is the appropriate State to tax such sales ... Clause b  contemplates a sale where the property in the goods sold is passed by a transfer of documents of title to them during their movement from one State to another.

arguments.claim: Physical transfer of documents (even without endorsement) in WB effects s.3(b) sale taxable there; delivery to railways not delivery to buyer.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated October 21, 1959, the Commercial Tax Officer made a best judgment assessment ... In case of goods consigned to Self there is no question that delivery to the railways cannot be constituted as delivery to the buyer But under the Sale of Goods Act, if a document of title to goods is used ...

arguments.court_reasoning: Transfer must pass property per agreement; not mere physical delivery.

arguments.claim: s.4(2) inapplicable to determine situs for inter-state s.3(b) sales; each section independent.

anchor.surface_text: The Taxing Officer of the Government of West Bengal did not accept the contention of the petitioner. He held In the case of sale u s 3 b no property in the goods passes unless the documents of title to goods are in the hands of the buyer. ... The dealer has said that section 4 2  lays down the principles ... In my opinion, this is an incorrect reading of the law. Each of section 3 and section 4 deals with quite independent sphere of commercial transactions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s reconsideration. We do number think however that the present is a fit case to go into the question whether the two cases are number reconcilable and

arguments.court_reasoning: s.4 subject to s.3; for inter-state, s.2(a) governs.

holdings.text: The petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is maintainable because the threat to recover again sales tax on the same sales already paid to Bihar prima facie infringes the fundamental right of the company to hold its property under Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Evidently, the company has paid to the Sales Tax Officer, Bihar, tax due under the Central Sales Tax Act on its turnover including sales on which the tax is sought to be levied by the Commercial Tax Officer, West Bengal. Under the Central Sales Tax Act, there is a single liability to pay tax on inter-State sales. The company having paid the tax to the Bihar State for and on behalf of the Central Government, the threat to recover again sales tax on behalf of the Central Government in respect of the same sales, i. e., sales which are included in the assessment proceedings before the Bihar Sales Tax authorities prima facie infringes the fundamental right of the company to hold its property and the company is entitled to approach this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Ramjilal and Laxmanappa; follows Himmatlal, Bengal Immunity; single tax liability under CST Act, double recovery threat violates Art.19(1)(g).

holdings.text: Under the Central Sales Tax Act, there is a single liability to pay tax on inter-State sales such that threat of recovery by two states infringes fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Central Sales Tax Act, there is a single liability to pay tax on inter-State sales. The company having paid the tax to the Bihar State for and on behalf of the Central Government, the threat to recover again sales tax on behalf of the Central Government in respect of the same sales, i. e., sales which are included in the assessment proceedings before the Bihar Sales Tax authorities prima facie infringes the fundamental right of the company to hold its property and the company is entitled to approach this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax levied once under s.6, collected by one appropriate state under s.9; double levy contrary to scheme.

holdings.text: Clauses (a) and (b) of Section 3 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 are mutually exclusive.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of an inter-State sale, the tax is leviable only once and that indicates that the two clauses of s. 3 are mutually exclusive. A sale taxable as falling within cl. a of s. 3, will be excluded from the purview of cl. b of s. 3 otherwise certain sales may, be liable to tax under both the clauses and two States may, in respect of a single sale, claim to levy the tax contrary to the plain intendment of ss. 6 and 9 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction to avoid double taxation; tax under s.6 only once, collected by one state under s.9; clauses divided into distinct categories.

holdings.text: A sale under s.3(b) is one effected by transfer of documents of title to the goods during their movement from one State to another whereby property in the goods passes.

anchor.surface_text: The sale contemplated by cl. b is one which is effected by transfer of documents of title to the goods during their movement from One State to another. Where the property in the goods has passed before the movement has commenced, the sale will evidently not fall within cl. b nor will the sale in which the property in the goods passes after the movement from one State to another has ceased be covered by the clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'effected by transfer'; property passes during movement (Explanations 1/2); excludes pre/post-movement transfers; mutually exclusive with s.3(a).

holdings.text: For sales under clause (b) of s.3, the appropriate State is the place where the sale is effected, i.e., where the transfer of documents of title occurs resulting in property passing.

anchor.surface_text: appropriate State was at the material time defined by s. 2 a as follows Appropriate State means- in relation to a dealer who has one or more places of business ... Explanation- Place of business means, in the case of a sale of goods in the course of inter- State trade or commerce falling within cl. a of s. 3, the place from which the goods have been moved ... cl. b of s. 3, the place where the sale is effected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(a) Expl.II defines place of business as 'where sale effected'; for s.3(b), transfer of doc title effects sale/passes property there; artificial but statutory fiction.

holdings.text: Section 4(2) of CST Act is subject to s.3 and does not determine situs/place where sale effected for inter-State sales under s.3(b); applies to non-inter-State sales only.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions contained in s.3 when a sale or purchase of goods is determined in accordance with sub-s. 2 to take place inside a State, such sale or purchase shall be deemed to have taken place outside all other States. A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place inside a State if the goods are within the State- a in the case of specific or ascertained goods, at the time the contract of sale is made and b in the case of unascertained or future goods, at the time of their appropriation to the contract of sale by the seller or by the buyer,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(1) expressly subject to s.3; s.4 formulates 'outside State' under Art.286(2); s.2(a) independently fixes for inter-State; no conflict.

holdings.text: The assessment order dated October 21, 1959 discloses an error apparent on its face as the CTO failed to apply correct tests for s.3(b), made unwarranted assumptions without evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No verification if goods in movement/doc transfer passed property/situs in WB per s.4(2) or s.2(a); mere physical transfer insufficient; best judgment invalid.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari issues quashing the assessment order; CTO to reassess applying correct tests.

anchor.surface_text: It will be for the Commercial Tax Officer of West Bengal to re-assess the company- pany in respect of transactions of sale which are properly taxable within the State of West Bengal by the application of the test which we have already set out. On this view, the rule is made absolute and it is directed that a writ of certiorari will issue quashing the order of assessment made by the Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta, West Bengal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error apparent warrants certiorari; liberty to reassess valid sales.

holdings.text: Clauses (a) and (b) of s.3 are mutually exclusive; s.3(b) requires property pass by doc title transfer during movement; appropriate State for s.3(b) is where transfer occurs (sale effected).

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order made by the Taxing Officer of the Government of West Bengal on October 21, 1959, assessing the petitioner to a tax of Rs. 41,14,718- 12nP.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Single tax incidence; avoids double tax; textual/purposive reading; s.2(a) Expl.II fixes situs independently of s.4(2).

justification_sets.label: Section 2(a) Central Sales Tax Act 1956 support
Section 2(a) Central Sales Tax Act 1956 support
Section 2(a) Central Sales Tax Act 1956 support

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment. It will be for the Commercial Tax Officer of West Bengal to re-assess the company in respect of transactions of sale which are properly taxable within the State of West Bengal by the application of the test which we have already set out.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ of certiorari issued quashing the assessment order dated October 21, 1959 by Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta. Liberty granted to reassess applying correct tests under sections 3 and 4 of Central Sales Tax Act.
directions: Commercial Tax Officer, West Bengal, to re-assess the company in respect of transactions of sale properly taxable within West Bengal by application of correct tests.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently, the company has paid to the Sales Tax Officer, Bihar, tax due under the Central Sales Tax Act on its turnover including sales on which the tax is sought to be levied by the Commercial Tax Officer, West Bengal. Under the Central Sales Tax Act, there is a single liability to pay tax on inter-State sales. The company having paid the tax to the Bihar State for and on behalf of the Central Government, the threat to recover again sales tax on behalf of the Central Government in respect of the same sales, i. e., sales which are included in the assessment proceedings before the Bihar Sales Tax authorities prima facie infringes the fundamental right of the company to hold its property and the company is entitled to approach this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment. It will be for the Commercial Tax Officer of West Bengal to re-assess the company in respect of transactions of sale which are properly taxable within the State of West Bengal by the application of the test which we have already set out.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of an inter-State sale, the tax is leviable only once and that indicates that the two clauses of s. 3 are mutually exclusive. A sale taxable as falling within cl. a of s. 3, will be excluded from the purview of cl. b of s. 3 otherwise certain sales may, be liable to tax under both the clauses and two States may, in respect of a single sale, claim to levy the tax contrary to the plain intendment of ss. 6 and 9 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The sale contemplated by cl. b is one which is effected by transfer of documents of title to the goods during their movement from One State to another. Where the property in the goods has passed before the movement has commenced, the sale will evidently not fall within cl. b nor will the sale in which the property in the goods passes after the movement from one State to another has ceased be covered by the clause.

The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment. anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions contained in s.3 when a sale or purchase of goods is determined in accordance with sub-s. 2 to take place inside a State, such sale or purchase shall be deemed to have taken place outside all other States. A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place inside a State if the goods are within the State- a in the case of specific or ascertained goods, at the time the contract of sale is made and b in the case of unascertained or future goods, at the time of their appropriation to the contract of sale by the seller or by the buyer,

anchor.surface_text: It will be for the Commercial Tax Officer of West Bengal to re-assess the company- pany in respect of transactions of sale which are properly taxable within the State of West Bengal by the application of the test which we have already set out. On this view, the rule is made absolute and it is directed that a writ of certiorari will issue quashing the order of assessment made by the Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta, West Bengal.

The Commercial Tax Officer has, in our view, failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted and on a true interpretation of the provisions of the Central Sales Tax Act, the order of assessment discloses an error apparent on its face and a writ of certiorari must issue quashing the assessment. It will be for the Commercial Tax Officer of West Bengal to re-assess the company in respect of transactions of sale which are properly taxable within the State of West Bengal by the application of the test which we have already set out.
